characters: PRESENTMENT SEALED IN TV NETWORK INQUIRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The luscious curves of a 1956 MERCEDES 190 coupe, lacquer dripping with bright showroom light. Circling: ™ DICK GOODWIN, late 20s, a broad Boston accent, his braing on his sleeve. Flush with youth and American confidence. chews a cigar as fat as a baby’s arm. A SALESMAN circles mosquito-like.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: What is this, the 190?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: That’s 17 coats of paint, hand-sanded. Seven coats of lacquer. Goodwin leans over. Looks at the sticker price. Sighs. Le back. Whistles low, drinks it in. ‘All this can be yours’

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: It takes a real individualist to drive a car like this. Just out of school?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Harvard Law. Couple of years. First in my class.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: -That degree’sells itself.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I've been working for the government.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: {disappointed) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Not that it’s permanent.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: (interested again) Would you like to get behind the wheel, Mr. Goodman?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Goodwin.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Just be careful with the cigar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Salesman opens the door. Ushers Goodwin into the car.

dialogues.speaker: . GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I just think there's something wrong about working so you can drive a car.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Release the clutch, if you wouldn’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You drive a car so that you can work. You don’t work so that you can drive a car. The Salesman leans over and starts the IGNITION.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Listen to,that. That’s a v8. {off gauges) You'll note it redlines at 3000 RPM.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: My father to this day has never owned a car. I don’t even think he has a driver’s license.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: That’s the American Dream. {resuming) I see you're admiring the dashboard--that’s burled walnut.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Is this what life has to offer?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Pretty much. (thinks) This or the Porsche, (resuming) The seats are Florentine glove leather.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: The nicest piece of furniture 1 own will be in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: I’m going to get some paperwork, just so you can see it’s more affordable than you think. (gestures to radio) Try the radio. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALESMAN (Cont‘d) The only thing that sounds better than the engine is the radio. The Salesman EXITS. Goodwin turns on the radio. It emits repetitive BEEP. He listens thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWSMAN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The Russians have beaten us into outer space. You are listening to the sound of Sputnik, a satellite launched this morning via rocket, in orbit right now directly over our heads...A sound that says... The Salesman returns, leans in. LISTENS.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWSMAN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ++-all is not well with America.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: America doesn’t own a Mercedes. CLICK! He pushes a button on the radio. Changes the stati MUSIC that carries over into...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The door of a BANK VAULT opens... INT. EVENING. BANK VAULT. Flashbulbs BURST as two BANK V.P.s insert separate keys i safe-deposit box. Pull out a BOX embossed with the title
The V.P.s’ heels click smartly on the marble. REPORTERS a PHOTOGRAPHERS follow them out to the street. A thick crow the curious. The V.P.s climb into an ARMORED CAR.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHERRYTOPS
dialogues.text: flash to life. The MOTORCADE roars uptown,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COMMUTERS stream out of the subway. Anxiously check their watches. RUN to their homes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A New York CABBIE flicks on his “OFF DUTY" light. Parks o street. Runs into a bar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PROJECTIONIST snaps off a movie in mid-scene. USHERS wh two TELEVISION SETS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MOTORCADE pulls up outside the RCA building. The Bank emerge, march inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one living room after another, HANDS reach for knobs o televisions...FIFTY MILLION VIEWERS across the nation...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TELEVISION
dialogues.text: JACK BARRY, late 30s. Part snake-oil salesman, part snake

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Good evening, I'm Jack Barry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright with klieg lights. A studio AUDIENCE twitchy with anticipation. Ponderous CAMERAS circle a podium that bear bold legend, “GERITOL”. He is flanked behind by two plexi ISOLATION BOOTHS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Due to a series of ties, Herbert Stempel, our 41 year old ex-GI college student, must Play at $3,000 a point, which means that in a few brief minutes he can either win over $100,000--the most money won on television to date--or lose everything he's won in the last eight weeks.

dialogues.speaker: LISTENING BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: The champ: HERBIE STEMPEL, Herbert the Great, early 40s a overweight. Marine haircut and shabby suit. A Job for his generation--exiled to the Boroughs, flayed by grey-flanne insults, scourged by lowly status, grudge-laden before Go The CHALLENGER watches as Herbie compulsively cleans his glasses. .

dialogues.speaker: CHALLENGER
dialogues.text: Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Heh. It’s only money.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON-
dialogues.text: as the Bank V.P.‘s deliver the questions, head offstage. “BARRY Thank you, gentlemen. {to audience) So right now, let’s meet our first two players, as Geritol, America’s Number One tonic, presents ‘21°. Two ESCORTS bring Herbie and the Challenger to the podium

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: The producers, DAN ENRIGHT and ALBERT FREEDMAN. Enright h soul of a shoplifter surprised to find himself in Tiffany Freedman is his willing right arm--until a better shoulde along. Enright snaps a SWITCH. An APPLAUSE SIGN ignites the audi BACK ON- - BARRY . as he greets Herbie and the Challenger.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: How are you, Herb? I imagine you're a kind of a folk hero out there in Queens.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NIGHT. SPONSOR’S APARTMENT. White walls. White carpet. White curtains. White furnitur a black heart--the grouchy SPONSOR of Geritol, early SOs. on the TELEVISION. A platinum BLONDE Serves him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: SPONSOR
dialogues.text: (with disgust) Queens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry interviews Herbie.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: It's a nervous strain on the family, huh? How’s your wife holding up?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: She‘s fine, -thank you. ‘Thank you, Mr. Barry, for asking. Barry launches into the rules.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: As you know, Herb, the questions, ‘which have been kept in a bank vault--

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting him) I might add she no longer suffers from ‘tired blood’, now that I've got her on Geritol.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SAME TIME. SPONSOR’S APARTMENT. The Sponsor BOILS while he watches Herbie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You know, Mr. Barry, while some people say that Geritol has no medical basis whatsoever, I can attest that it’s a fine product.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buzz of genteel conversation. Tweeds and sherry. A BO PARTY in honor of THE PROFESSOR, MARK VAN DOREN, late 50s white-haired gent with a beatific demeanor, and his brisk articulate wife DOROTHY, late 50s also. Stacks of their n BOOKS nearby. They greet a stream of GUESTS.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: {shaking hands) Professor.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Professor.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I’m late. You can't get a cab.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (greeting The Professor) Professor.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Professor.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Professor.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: {to Dorothy) Mother, where’s Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: ALONE IN THE DEN
dialogues.text: Hand on chin, MESMERIZED, the blue light of a TELEVISION on his chiselled features: CHARLES VAN DOREN, 30s, handsome, well-born, debonair, self-deprecating, perfect. The lithe build of a man who h never been made to run uphill. An endearing blankness--th boyish availability of a man still in search of himself. A pretty YOUNG WOMAN, early 20s, approaches. Ignored by C she tries to start conversation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Professor Van Doren?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh--how rude of me. (introducing himself) I’m Charlie. (beat) He’s my father.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: I took his course at Columbia--‘Hawthorne, Original Sin and the American Experience’--well, as silly as it sounds, it changed my life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Was it the Hawthorne or the sin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be the son of that extraordinary man!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: When you said that, ‘Professor Van Doren‘ --you know, I'm also Professor Van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Mathematics? You seem like the -Mathematical type.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Literature. Same as Dad.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Really? Where do you teach?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC plays and the two Escorts usher Herbie and the Chal to the ISOLATION BOOTHS.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Once inside the isolation booth, neither player can see the other. (more) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BARRY (Cont‘d) Nor can they hear anything until I turn their studios on, (flipping switch) Can you hear me, Herb?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Barry, I sure can.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: Enright’s gaze sweeps hawklike over the monitors,

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Herb’s too sure of himself. Turn off the air conditioning in his booth. Freedman slides up a THERMOSTAT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin sits on a couch--a waiting room outside the offic the President of NBC. A huge NBC PEACOCK over his head.

dialogues.speaker: A MONITOR
dialogues.text: -shows Herbie patting at his sweaty brow with a HANDKERCH ‘Goodwin gets up; crosses in front of the ‘Image.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The first category is the American Revolution. A SECRETARY sits at a desk nearby. Goodwin approaches her

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Do you think he might see me before the peacock molts?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Kintner apologizes, but he’s unavailable. Why don’t you come back tomorrow?.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I’m sure he'd be available if my name were Geritol.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Who were you with again? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: The United States Congress --perhaps you've heard of them. I spoke to Mr. Kintner personally six weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: The President of NBC never speaks personally with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: The committee oversees television, Kintner makes his speech about television being a public trust and I take notes. It’s simply a matter of routine.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Isn‘t everything? Goodwin moves away, DEFEATED. The Secretary returns to he Goodwin returns, nods toward the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: They do that show right here?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Studio 21. Tenth floor.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 1s INT. SAME TIME. STUDIO. Herbie chews a knuckle. Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: The American Revolution...I‘11 try 11, 11 points, Mr. Barry--if that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Let me remind you that the questions have been certified and graded for difficulty by the Encylopedia Britannica on a scale from one to. 11--11 being the hardest question.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: That's right, Mr. Barry. Barry, impressed by Herbie's daredevil bid, presses a but and a QUESTION CARD pops up... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: (reading) The question is in five Parts. ‘Every schoolboy knows about the midnight ride of Paul Revere. For 11 points: How Many lanterns were hung in the Old North Church? Who rode with Paul Revere? Who lent him his horse? Was it a mare Or a stallion? And what was the horse’s name?! What a question! An audible GASP from the audience. Herbi grimaces, hugs his elbows, bites his lip, scratches his h looks skyward for divine inspiration. :

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Would you mind, Mr. Barry- -could I take the third part last?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SAME TIME. SPONSOR‘’S HOME. The Sponsor broods over the TV.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The code was ‘One if by land, two if by sea. Therefore it was lanterns in the steeple of the Old North’ Church. The Blonde enters with ROBERT KINTNER, 50s, a manner whip smooth as a meringue.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: (announcing) Mr. Kintner.

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: I understand you're upset, sirc--the ratings are slightly off--

dialogues.speaker: SPONSOR
dialogues.text: The ratings are off because of hin He jabs a bony finger.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TELEVISION
dialogues.text: Herbie mops his brow, struggles through the question. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Dawes and Prescott were the men who rode with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign reads “QUIET--SHOW IN PROGRESS". Goodwin stops at STAGE DOOR. Thinks a beat. OPENS it and enters the MEZZAN Leans against the back wall. Watches the stage below:

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Was it a mare or a stallion?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: It was a mare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SANDRA, Goodwin's pretty shikse wife, watches from the fo the bed in their one-bedroom Georgetown apartment.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: What’s the last part again?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The third part?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: No--I asked for the third part last.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: That’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I just don’t remember the last part.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Who remembers the question? That‘s harder than the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin looks down from the mezzanine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: What was the horse’s name? HERBIE . The horse's name was Brown Beauty.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: And finally, the man who loaned Paul Revere his horse for that fateful midnight ride?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Who loaned him the horse...who loaned him the horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enright and Freedman exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: ---Who loaned him the horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Charlie wracks his brain, watches with the young woman.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (searching) -;-Something tells me it was a clergyman...Reverend Luckbill...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SAME TIME. SPONSOR‘S APARTMENT. Kintner and the scowling Sponsor watch the show.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ++-Reverend Larchwood...Reverend Lardbone...

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER _
dialogues.text: It’s not easy to find suitable contestants. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SPONSOR
dialogues.text: Do the show on the Sabbath. Just get rid of him. The Sponsor exits. The Blonde arrives with Kintner’s hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anxious VIEWERS move to the edge of their Seats...Somewhe phone rings unanswered, a child cries unheard...A can of FREEZES in mid-sip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin leaning forward in anticipation...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Would you like more time, Herb? Herbie curls into himself...Then Pops UP...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Larkin! Deacon John Larkin!

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Correct for 11 points!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MEZZANINE
dialogues.text: Goodwin shakes his head in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: How the hell did he know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie chews his lip in awed respect.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My God, he knows ing. I'd bet even Dad wouldn’t know that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Professor Van Doren--can you imagine? He wouldn‘t be caught dead on one of these quiz shows!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the wheels SPIN...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. You're quite right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry delivers the commercial

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Do you feel fatigued? Not having as much fun as you used to? Does life itself seem to be getting you down? The problem may be tired blood. (meaningfully) Tired blood.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ISOLATION BOOTH
dialogues.text: The INTERCOM crackles on. “ENRIGHT (0.C.) Nice job, Herbie. You can relax a minute. Herbie sags. Mops under his arms with the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Christ. Again with the air conditioning.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Freedman answers it. Turns to Enright. It’s Kintner.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 27 28 29 16. INT. NIGHT. TIMES SQUARE STATION. An ebullient Herbie descends into the subway. Tonight, he Kelly. Humming a tune, he dances down the stairs. The F t arrives, and he scoots inside. PASSENGERS recognize him, point. Studiously nonchalant, h ignores them, Sinks down into his overcoat. And SMILES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbie walks through his tidy neighborhood. In his home c now...NEIGHBORS shake his hand, slap his back... He climbs the stairs to his house. Across the street, a n APPLAUDS from a second story window. Herbie bows elaborat enters his house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NIGHT. HERBIE’S APARTMENT. Herbie enters, takes off his hat. HERBIE ; The genius is home! The rich genius is home!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE. LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: TOBY STEMPEL, late 30s, wedged heavily in an armchair. A Devil Dogs in her lap. She searches for a chunk of cake l the folds of her muumuu. Herbie enters.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Did you see me? Toby, wasn’t I great? Wasn‘t I incredible? And that bit about Geritol--did I play them like a piano or what? (locking in mirror) What about my teeth--d’you think I should get my teeth capped? How‘d my hair look?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Could I take the third part last, Mr. Barry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninety-six thousand dollars! C'mon, dance with me, Toby. C’mont We're celebrating! He pulls and hauls at her with the exertions of a deep se fisherman. But she’s having none of it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Stop it, Herbert.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: (croons) ‘Dancing in the dark, until the tune ends...’

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I told Lester to be home by ten. He'll be here any minute.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Come on! A child can’t see his Parents dancing? Be a good wife.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: If you knew how my ankles feel you wouldn’t ask. Herbie gives up. Moves to the mirror. Starts to strip off tie, his SUIT...

dialogues.speaker: " HERBIE
dialogues.text: Why do you think your ankles hurt? Eat some more.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I‘m retaining water, for your information.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You and the Grand Coulee Dam. He throws the suit jacket in a ball on the floor. Starts strip off the pants. Toby stands, bends to pick the jacke Dusts it off...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You don’t get it, do you? I go out on the street and everybody knows me. Everybedy loves me--me--Herbie Stempel. And they love me for the same reason they used to hate me. Because I'm the guy who knows everything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Do you know how much it’s gonna cost to get this suit dry-cleaned?

dialogues.speaker: . HERBIE
dialogues.text: Things are going to change around here, boy. Herbie throws the pants on the floor. In his SHORTS now.. The “PHONE

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (dusting suit) Look at this. My father paid good money for this suit.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: He wore it to his own wake!

dialogues.speaker: ,_ TOBY
dialogues.text: You make it sound like it was the suit that killed him.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You know why Enright likes that suit? You know why he personally picked that suit out of my closet? Because it makes me look like a . ‘The poor ex-GI’ with the hand-me-down suit and the walk-up apartment. RINGS..-Toby goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You should worship the ground I walk on, all my family’s done for you.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You want to be worshipped, go to India and moo.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I married a man who couldn’t hold onto a dollar if he swallowed it. (to phone) Hello? Yeah, hi, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Cock-a-doodle-doo, baby--I’m not the putz you married. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hangs

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (to phone) That’s Herbie. He’s in one of hig moods. (listens) Of course I watched the show.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Get off the phone--Steve Allen might call. Eisenhower might call. You think I’m kidding?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: She wants to know why you only went for eight on the movies.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Because my real area of expertise is pain-in-the-ass in-laws. “TOBY {to phone) I_know everybody‘s watching. (listens) I’ know it’s a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Hang up the phone. Hang it--would you please hang up the phone?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (to phone) I gotta go. He says Etsenhower’s gonna call. I’11] call you tomorrow. up.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Just sit. Sit with me. What is it with you? He sits on the couch. She sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You better put some clothes on. You‘’1l catch cold.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Toby, listen. Don’t you see what this means for us?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You gonna leave me, Herbie? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: No, I'm not gonna leave you. Don’t you understand? It’s a revolution! For us. Everything--all of this. We don’t need your mother and her money anymore--you can tell her where to get off after 38 years.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You should hear all of a sudden how nice she’s being.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: (gestures to television) That box is the biggest thing since Gutenberg invented the printing press, and I’m the biggest thing on it. Don’t you see? I could be on this show forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pegboard and cheap furniture. Charlie sits Opposite a RES who TESTS him from a list of questions. There’s a MIRROR wall behind them.

dialogues.speaker: RESEARCHER
dialogues.text: (reading from card) ‘Because of a disagreement with his commanding general, Ulysses S. Grant was virtually placed under arrest for a brief time early in 1862. Who was the commanding general of the Union Army at that time?’

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I know that! Halleck. General H.W. Halleck.

dialogues.speaker: RESEARCHER
dialogues.text: That’s correct. Charlie nervously rubs his sweaty palms on his knees. Tri lean over to peek at the Researcher‘s tally.

dialogues.speaker: WATCHING HIM
dialogues.text: through a ONE-WAY MIRROR: Freedman. A PAGE passes through (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: PAGE
dialogues.text: (off roster) Charles Van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Van Doren like Van Doren Van Doren? He wants to he on 'Tic Tac Dough’? The Page shrugs. Freedman licks his chops...

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Let me borrow this a second. He grabs Charlie’s. file. Runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freedman runs with the file, virtually singing...

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got him...I’ve got the guy...This is the guy...I've got the guy... ‘CUT TO: INT. DAY. ENRIGHT’S OFFICE A spectacular S0th floor aerie with Art Deco furniture. E gazes out at his view. Turns as Freedman arrives.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got the guy.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LATER. ENRIGHT’S OFFICE. Enright appraises Charlie like a cattle rancher eyeballin prize bull. Freedman can barely contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ---Well, originally I was going to be a concert pianist. (more) (CONTINUED)

CHARLIE (Cont‘d) And I was really quite good, but when the day was done, no Horowitz. So I decided to be an actor. Or a philosopher--I studied the Great Books at St. John's. I realized I'd never really excel at either of those, so I turned to astrophysics. But of course all the great physicists made their discoveries before the age of 25. That just wasn’t in the cards. So I went to the West Bank and wrote a novel, about a parricide--

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: -CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A boy who kills his father. My Dad liked it quite a lot, actually. But it’s not like he equated it to Hawthorne or anything. It just seemed--do you know that Johnson remark, ‘the epidemical conspiracy for the destruction of paper’? I mean, you could fill Yankee Stadium with all the mediocre novelists in the . world, and--

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Could I ask you a personal question? How much do they pay you up at Columbia?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Eighty-six dollars a week.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Do you know how much the average stockbroker is paid? Do you have any idea what Bozo the Clown makes?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, we can’t all be Bozo the Clown.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m not questioning your choice of profession--not at all. (more) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ENRIGHT (Cont‘d) I’m questioning the values of a society that pays somebody like you--what was it?

dialogues.speaker: . FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Eighty-six dollars a week.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Eighty-six dollars a week, and meanwhile Sputnik’s up there cight now beep-beep-beeping over our heads.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I have to admit, Mr. Enright, it’s a national problem.

dialogues.speaker: -ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I understand you came down here to try out for ‘Tic Tac Dough’.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, my friends say I have a good mind for this sort of thing--I'd been planning a trip to Italy, and- -

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: How would you like to be on ’21'? “CHARLIE "21°?

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Dan produces both shows.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You‘re young, clean-cut...From a prominent family. You're exactly what this country needs. Kids would run to do their homework so they could be like Charles Van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s just--what about Herbert Stempel?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I love Herbie. People don’t like him, Kids don’t look up to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: If you were a kid, would you want to grow up and be a fat, annoying Jewish guy with a sidewall haircut?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to he Joe DiMaggio.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Especially after he held out for the hundred grand.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: That’s what this country needs. An intellectual Joe DiMaggio, with the money and the women and all from this (tapping his head) instead of a bat and ball.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All that aside--well, honestly, I_don‘t think I can beat him. ‘Tic Tac Dough’ seemed more feasible. Enright thinks a beat. Gazes out the window.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: What if we were to put you on the show--put you on ‘21’ this Wednesday--and ask you “questions you know? Say, the questions you already answered correctly on your test this morning?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? r thought the questions were in a bank vault.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Forget about that. I’m just thinking out loud.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You want to win, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think I’d really rather try to beat him honestly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: What‘s dishonest? It’s not like we'd be giving you the answers,

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE,
dialogues.text: I don’t see the difference.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: We ask you a question, you know the answer. Just because we know you know, you still know.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s not like putting me on the show, or Al, and pretending I’m some intellectual. You've put in the time, years of study and erudition. “CHARLIE (wondering) I’m just trying to imagine, what would Kant think of this?

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: I really don’t think he'd have a problem with it.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Nobody would ever have to know. Just .us three. Think of what you'd accomplish for the cause of education.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It just doesn’t seem right. I'd have to say no.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Just an idea, An awkward heat as they all look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Was that part of the test? 34 INT. LATER. HALLWAY. Enright and Freedman usher Charlie to the elevator. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Wednesday, Professor. Say around P-m. for the run-through.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It‘ll be, I assume--that is, not the way we discussed before. Aboveboard.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: So pure it floats.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You‘re on your own.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Weil, a pleasure to meet you both. Goodbye. He exits into the elevator. Enright turns to Freedman.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Get me those questions. 35 INT. NIGHT. TOOTS SHOR‘S. Herbie watches a competing quiz show at a crowded bar, TO _ SHOR, the celebrated proprietor, beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TELEVISION
dialogues.text: an EMCEE asks a question.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (reading) "Surgeon, soldier, sailor, spy, dreamed Thurber’s great creation. Though Walter’s life was mighty dry, he had imagination’. Name that story.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON--THE BAR
dialogues.text: as Toots shakes his head in dismay, whistles low.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: ‘The Secret Life of Walter Mitty’. Toots looks over at Herbie, doubletakes as he recognizes (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TELEVISION
dialogues.text: as the Contestant flounders and the bell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You don’t know? (buzzer) ‘The Secret Life of Walter Mitty’. According to the rules of *Dotto’, the 10 dots you asked for will now be connected in your Opponent ‘s picture... An ARTIST works at a large easel--a CARICATURE forming...

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON--THE BAR
dialogues.text: as Toots nudges Herbie.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Excuse me--are you Herbert Stempel?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I am.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Holy Toledo. Toots Shor. (to man alongside) Lockit--Herb Stempel. From television. The guy that knows “everything.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN ALONGSIDE
dialogues.text: turns from his drink. Offers his hand. It’s JOE LOUIS.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Hiya, champ.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: (off Herbie) This guy’s the Joe Louis of brains. Enright ARRIVES, taps Herbie on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late. Herbie digs to pay for his drink. Toots waves him off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: On the arm. You need anything--it’s my jernt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbie and Enright chew Pleasurably through thick steaks. Enright offers up a venerable Bordeaux.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: More wine, Herb?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dan. Why not? Enright pours the wine.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You‘ve earned it. How's that steak?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Nothing like a fine piece of meat.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You know, it’s a hell of a thing. I’m looking at the thing Loday--you know, the Trendex ratings: -

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Well, it’s the damnedest thing. You've plateaued.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I've plateaued? What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: The ratings have plateaued.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You just told me the other day the ratings were up.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: They were up. And now they’ve plateaued. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: ‘Plateaued’--what kind of word is that? You mean people don’t like me any more?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s not you per se, it’s just--well, regrettably, the viewing public is fickle.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Maybe I should get my teeth capped.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s the answer.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You know what I think it is? I think people are tired of that whole ‘GI college student’ thing. Frankly, I’m tired of it myself. And that disgusting suit--I mean, that’s gotta be half of it--

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s not you, Herb. It’s just the nature of the show. They‘ve already seen you win. They’re bored with it. “HERBIE What are you saying? You think they want me to lose?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Don’t you think that's natural?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You’re panicking. The ratings'11l come around. This is temporary. (gestures inside) Look at Joe Louis. Joe Louis was the champ for twelve years. Nobody ever wanted Joe Louis to lose.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I'm saying just think about it. Think about the little people.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Little people and big money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Think about all you’ve done for the cause of education.

dialogues.speaker: . HERBIE
dialogues.text: The cause of education? I waited 41 years for this! Now I'm Supposed to take a dive for the fucking cause of education?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I thought we had a relationship, Herb. I’m asking you for your help.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Fine. Just let me play it honestly. A WAITER walks by.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Will you please keep your voice down?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You don’t think I could do it? Go ahead. Give me a number. Enright rolls his eyes. Herbie stops a WAITER. “HERBIE {to Waiter) Give me a number. A random number.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You're making a spectacle of yourself, The Waiter continues on.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: 23. Beethoven was 23 when he composed his first piano sonata. In 1923 Jack Bentley set the record for batting average by a pitcher, hitting .427. There are 23 chromosomes in the human egg. Also the human sperm. 23rd President of the United States? Benjamin Harrison. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Herb- -

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Asian countries along the 23rd parallel of southern latitude--Australia, Tonga, French Polynesia- -

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Don’t start believing your own bullshit. You wouldn’t know the name cf Paul Revere's horse if he took a crap on your lawn.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: She.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: It was a mare, remember?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: The point is I helped you and now you owe me. You lose when I tell you to lose.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: ~ But why. now?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s an arrangement--it’s always been an arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: If you made me lose before, if you made me lose right from the beginning, that I‘d understand--that‘d be my whole fucking life. But why now?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Nothing lives forever.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Producers and viruses live forever.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Look at the big picture. It’s not like television is going to go away, you know. Think about the future.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: The future? What are you talking about, the future? I mean, specifically.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: If I knew, I'd write horoscopes for a living. (to the Waiter) Check?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You mean like a panel show?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Haven’t I taken care of you? Haven't I been like a Dutch uncle to you?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Down to the wooden shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Just trust me. The Waiter brings the check. Enright goes over it.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You know, I could be terrific on one of those panel shows. Witty, off-the-cuff. Sort of a Bill Cullen thing--

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: The last category is movies. We're gonna ask you what won the Academy Award for 1955. You don't know it.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: (sagging) Oh, no. Oh, no. Don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You blank. You don’t remember it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I saw ‘Marty’ three times! How can I lose on ‘Marty’? The Best Picture from a year ago and I don't know it?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: That’s the whole point.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: It’s not enough te take my championship away--you have to zetz me in front of the entire country!

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Someone of your intellect and it's such a simple question--don't you see the drama of that? HERBIE . But ‘Marty’? I'm begging you, Dan, Something else. Let me lose on a physics question. Herbie gets on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Herb, will you get off the floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Not ‘Marty’. It’s too humiliating. Enright hands a FIFTY to the waiter. Looks down at Herbie

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: For 96 grand, Herb, you can afford to be humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A one bedroom in Georgetown. SANDRA, 203, Goodwin's prett Shikse wife, does a crossword puzzle while she watches TV bed. Goodwin enters, a huge CIGAR smoldering in his mouth

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: No cigar in the bedroom. Goodwin retreats into the hallway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: (muttering) No cigar in the bedroom. we allow a television in the bedroom but there’s no cigar in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Goodwin sits, taps an ash into his pants cufé.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (from inside) How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: That bad?.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Teday the Chairman asked me to write a speech for him, to deliver to the Kiwanis Club of Fayetteville, Arkansas.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You’re good at that.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: It’s supposed to be an investigative committee.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It’s 1957, Dick. What are you gonna investigate?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TELEVISION
dialogues.text: an ad for Geritol.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Do you feel fatigued in the afternoon? Not having as much fun as you used to?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON- -GOODWIN
dialogues.text: puffing his cigar in the hallway...

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: {from inside) What ever happened with that wall Street job? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Money isn’t everything, you know.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I’m not the one who came back from New York with a Mercedes catalogue.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I just had this idea x was gonna do something with my life.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It‘s a job, Dick. It’s not sex.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: That degree was supposed to be a ticket to something different. This isn’t different. This is a different way of being the same.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BEDRCOM
dialogues.text: Sandra watches the television. Goodwin enters.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You ever hear of Charles van Doren?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Van Doren like Van Doren van Doren?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: He's going to be on a quiz show.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TELEVISION
dialogues.text: an ANNOUNCER delivers a PROMO.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ..-he’s a professor at Columbia University in the fabled Ivy League. And he'll be the new challenger this week on ‘211

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NIGHT. HERBIE’S APARTMENT. Herbie watches the same promo in his living room. His 10-year-old son LESTER, a pint-sized Herbie complete with glasses, sits next to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sounds of She takes They exit. 36. I h HERBIE ‘m such a schmuck. (to Lester) Your father’s a schmuck.

dialogues.speaker: . ANNOUNCER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Will Herbert Stempel become the first man to win over $100,000 on television?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: No, Herbert Stempel won’t win over $100,000. Herbert Stempel is going to take a dive!

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: +;-Tune in Wednesday and watch the best of CCNY take on the best 3f the Ivy League--this week on ‘214

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Tune in and watch Herb Stempel get fed to the Columbia Lions. Tune in and watch Charles Van Doren eat his first kosher meal, this week on ‘217! the front door unlocking...Toby enters in her coat,

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: What are you.doing, keeping. Lester up like this?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: The child has to learn. The child has to learn the depths that humanity can sink to. Lester by the hand, leads him out.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: He wouldn’t let me practice my drums.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You’re going to give him your ulcer. Let him grow up with his own ulcer. Herbie stares at the television. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Why? What did I do? I did everything they said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor reads in their tiny book-cluttered office t share. Charlie noisily loads his briefcase. The Professor doesn’t notice. Charlie moves to the door. Then turns, CHARLIE ° Have you ever watched one of those quiz shows on television?

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: You know we don’t own a television, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I just thought you might have seen one somewhere. ‘The $64,000 Question’, or ‘21'?

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: For $64,000 I hope they ask you the meaning of life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (defensive) It‘s like a competition.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: You know--I don't think I know a single person who’s ever seen one!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’ve been told $0 million people watch those shows.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Well, then, I suppose we've become a nation of proctors. They turn on the television and watch a quiz? : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know, apparently these shows have done a lot to enhance the image of intellectuals in this country, motivate schoolchildren--

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I’m sure they’re harmless, (changes the subject) You know, the Tates are in town, we're meeting them for dinner, Would you like to join us?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. I have, uh...an appointment with destiny.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (winks) Give her a. kiss for me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (winks) I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Barry rehearses while a DIRECTOR counts off. o

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (different readings) ‘Good evening, I’m Jack Barry’. ‘Good evening, I‘m Jack Barry’. ‘Good evening, I'm Jack Barry’. The Director signals.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Good evening, I'm Jack Barry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby eats oranges, drops the peels into a paper sack... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ---Returning with $96,000, from Forest Hills, New York, Mr. Herbert Stempel... INT. SAME TIME. SPONSOR'S APARTMENT. The Sponsor and Kintner watch in the all-white space,

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: ++-and from New York City, Professor Charles Van Doren...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry interviews Charlie. Herbie fidgets alongside.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Professor, are you in any way related to Mark Van Doren, the famous writer?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s my father, Jack. Dorothy van Doren,. the author of the recent "The Country Wife’, is my mother, and Carl Van Doren, the biographer of Benjamin Franklin, was my uncle.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: Freedman leans in to a pensive Enright. Whispers.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Herbie’s acting funny. You sure he’s on board?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON-
dialogues.text: as he turns to Herbie.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Herb, you have a chance tonight to win over $100,000--not bad for an ex-GI college student. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Honestly, Mr. Barry, I feel that--win or lose--I‘ve already shown exactly what it takes for aman in this country to rise above his circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: . BARRY
dialogues.text: Only in America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Goodwins eat Chinese food out of cartons, watch Charl the TV.

dialogues.speaker: . SANDRA
dialogues.text: Look at him. He’s dreamy.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: ‘Dreamy’? The man is a college professor,

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You know I like brainy guys.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You never said Herbert Stempel was .dreamy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A condensation of the game as Charlie and Herbie, lip-bit brow-mopping, bat the lead back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: +.-Andrew Johnson of Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: --.I guess, I guess that Atahualpa was the leader of the Incas at the time of the conquest...

dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)
++-therefore the Virgin Islands must be Columbus's second voyage...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ...The --wouldn’t that be Patterson, Joseph Patterson?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ...If I could take that third part last...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: :+-I’d like to take the thira part last, if I might...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Correct, Herb, for 8 points!

dialogues.speaker: -BARRY

dialogues.text: Did Herbert Stempel send you?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN

dialogues.speaker: SCHWEITZER
dialogues.text: You tell your friend Stempel that that presentment lies in a deep cold grave, and the only way he’s going to get his hands on it is to join it there. Now you get out of here, or I’m going to hold you in contempt! The Judge nods to the burly Bailiff, who heads toward Goo Goodwin gathers his. papers, scrambles out.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Mr. Stempel? My name is Richard Goodwin, I’m a lawyer with the Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight of the United States congress.

dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Well, I’d like to talk to you about it. Herbie blinks. He can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Gee, uh. Ha! Finally! Finally! Come in. What‘s your name, Goodwin? {calling inside} Hey, Toby, get dressed, willya? There‘s somebody here from Congress!

dialogues.text: INT. LATER. HERBIE‘S APARTMENT. They enter the living room. Toby watches the TV. Sounds o Herbie’s son Lester DRUMMING wildly inside.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I_ knew it was just a matter of time. This is my wife, Toby. This is Mr. Goodwin, he’s an . investigator from. the United States Congress.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rubber Crutch here thinks I should‘ve kept my mouth shut.

dialogues.text: 1957 and I still believe in miracles. She gets up. Heads toward the kitchen....

dialogues.text: Quashed.

dialogues.speaker: ... HERBIE
dialogues.text: Quashed?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Not squashed. Quashed.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Not in a million years, quashed, okay?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Of course not. Him they would have to listen to. The man’s name is open, sesame. Toby returns with a pot of coffee and a plate of rugulach

dialogues.text: Come oni You don’t look like you have a weight problem. {calling inside) Lester! Willya knock it off for ten minutes! (with rugalach) They don‘t have this in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: No, thank you. “HERBIE It's a Jewish delicacy. You don’t know what you’re missing.

dialogues.text: I’m quite familiar with rugalach, thank you. Herbie realizes that Goodwin is Jewish...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, .really?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Did Herbie tell you he went to the newspapers? Not one would print his story.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Being a voice alone in the wilderness, you know, that’s one thing. Being a voice alone in Forest Hills, that’s quite another.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Seventeen newspapers in the City of New York.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: If Charles Van Doren went to the papers--can you imagine the headlines? ‘Van Doren Blows Whistle on Quiz Fix’. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . GOODWIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fix. (shouting) Lester!

dialogues.speaker: TOBY

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to ask him questions. He’s here to ask me questions.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I just want to get this straight--'21' is fixed?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You‘re so naive. Of course it’s fixed! It‘'s a fix, it’s all a fix. A set-up.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: That‘s unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Do--you think that: big blond putz would be on the show 13 weeks without somebody spoon- feeding him the answers? Herbie tears into the rugalach.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You’re saying Charles Van Doren is given the answers in advance?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: They made me take a dive--did you know that? ‘Marty’. They told me I had ‘plateaued‘--that the ratings had ‘plateaued’.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: A sinking ship and the rats stayed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Would they tell me to take a dive and not give him the answers? It’s not logical.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Then it’s purely inferential.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: There's nothing inferential about it. You think they’d give me the answers, who didn’t even need the answers, and not give the Big Goy the answers ?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: They gave you the answers? SURPRISED, Toby shoots him a look--this is the first she’ of it. An awkward PAUSE, filled with the sound of Lester‘ drumming...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Would you please go inside and tell Gene Krupa to take five? Toby gets up, goes inside. Herbie resumes.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Herb--why would you admit that they gave.you the answers?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. Exactly. That‘s the difference between me and Charles Van Doren--I admit it. I have my morality.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I want te get this straight--they made you take a dive after giving you the answers.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I just wanted the money--frankly, to get out from under the financial thumb, as it were, of my in-laws. I didn’t put myself up to the world as the Crown Prince of Education. I didn’t parade myself on the cover of Time. That’s why you have to nail hin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . GOODWIN
dialogues.text: This isn‘t McCarthyism.

dialogues.speaker: . HERBIE
dialogues.text: Listen--think about what McCarthyism did for McCarthy.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I’m not here to nail anyone.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I'm just saying--don’t make necessarily the mistakes that I might have made in life. Think about your career. You nail Van Doren, kid, it‘ll be bigger than Sputnik. It‘’d be like Sputnik crashing--like a big blond Sputnik crashing right on his fucking ead. : EXT. DAY. COLUMBIA CAMPUS. STUDENTS greet Charlie as he strides across campus. A man element. Then he notices Goodwin following him. Starts to Looks over his shoulder. Still being followed...

dialogues.speaker: .. GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Professor Van Doren! Charlie at a trot now...Goodwin runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE DASHES
dialogues.text: at a dead run across the Quad. Goodwin picks up the pursu

dialogues.text: into the library, hustling through as STUDENTS greet him.

dialogues.speaker: HIDE AND SEEK
dialogues.text: behind a large CARD CATALOGUE. Goodwin hurries by. Charli peeks. Sneaks down a hallway. Stops at the elevator. Poun on the button as he looks around furtively.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Darn. Goodwin looks around. Backtracks down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TURNS THE CORNER
dialogues.text: sees Charlie, hiding his face with his newspaper, pressin urgently on the elevator button. Runs up to him.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Professor Van Doren! Excuse me--my name is Richard Goodwin. I'ma lawyer with--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank God! Excuse me--I thought you were a stockbroker.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: A lawyer's bad enough. Professor--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nobody without acne gets to call me Professor. Call me Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Do you have a minute?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sure. We can go up to my office, if this elevator ever gets here. Charlie punches the button again.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You krow, ‘you look like -someone I know. Now isn’t that funny? I’ve forgotten his name.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: My mother says I look like Tony Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, that‘s not it... The elevator arrives. Charlie gestures for Goodwin to ent first. Then suddenly stops him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Stempel! Remember him? That’s who you look like--Herbert Stempel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ---I almost became a lawyer. But there’s only nine seats on the Supreme Court, after all, and--where’d you go to law school? Charlie unlocks his office, gestures for Goodwin to enter

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Harvard. I was first in my class.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good for you. Did you know Professor Byse at all?

dialogues.speaker: -GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He taught me Contracts.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He taught me my backhand. That's him up there with Dad and Roosevelt. Goodwin inspects the MEMORABILIA on the mantle: Mark Van with Clack Byse and FDR. Mark Van Doren and Hemingway. Th National Book Award. The Pulitzer Prize.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So, you must be happy to flee Our Nation’s Capital.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Then you've spent some time there.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Washington? Washington’s a town where for excitement they go to Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Let me ask you--have you heard anything about these allegations that ‘21’ was rigged?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Rigged?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Fixed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What an odd idea...I don’t even know how you'd go about it.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: So you've never noticed anything suspect about the show?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Its popularity is, I suppose, suspect,

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Herbert Stempel says that during his reign on ‘21° he was given the answers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Herbert Stempel? I‘d’ve thought they got the answers from him.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He also says he was made to take a dive in his contest with you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I‘d hate to think I won anything but fairly.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You’ve never been asked to do anything improper?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, no.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Because if you were, you know, they'd just be using you for your name. You’d be a victim as much as anyone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Frankly, I wish they would. I’a love to take a dive and get back to normal life.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR OPENS
dialogues.text: and The Professor enters.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Oh. Hello, Charlie. Am I interrupting? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dick, this is my father, Mark van Doren. This is Dick Goldwyn.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Goodwin. It’s an honer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Goodwin--what a wonderful name! ‘Good.’ ‘Win’. All of America is in that name,

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you happen to see the show last night?

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: It was on last night? I'm sorry, Charlie, I--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's nothing, it’s just--there was a question about Hawthorne. i thought you'd get a kick out of it.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR

dialogues.speaker: "GOODWIN

dialogues.text: Are you a card player, Dick? We have a regular game Saturday nights, we’re looking for someone to fill in.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I_don‘t know that I’m a card Player. I’ve played cards before.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The address is--actually, why don’t we drive up together? I'll pick you up around 7:30. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Dick, if you lock around the table and can’t tell who the sucker is--it’s you. They all share a big laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie talks on a PAY PHONE on Broadway, tearing at his and looking around furtively.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ++-I simply can’t have this. He was questioning me! “ENRIGHT {0.C.) Calm down. His wife probably wanted an autograph.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Congress investigates Communists. Congress investigates mobsters. Those are not our people.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Look on the bright side--you’ll » --be.on national television. (beat) That’s a joke, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You gave Herbert Stempel the answers? You never told me that!

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: It never came up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You said I could never beat him without getting the answers.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I_ said you'd advance the cause of education. Was I right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why is he doing this? He’s only implicating himself! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: A PASSERBY
dialogues.text: recognizes Charlie. Points at him.

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: Hey! It’s Charles Van Doren! Charlie tries to hide in the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Think about the future. Do you know hew many calls I get from the network about you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don‘t understand. I have a name.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: That's what I’m telling you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I am Charles van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PASSERBY
dialogues.text: as others CROWD around him, stop to gawk.

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: Look--Charles Van Doren! Hey, - Professor --you calling Information? ‘He's calling 411 for Information.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON- -CHARLIE
dialogues.text: as he struggles. Flashes a phony smile to the GAWKERS.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I have something that’s gonna make Herbie go away. I guarantee it. Just don’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (flustered) I have to--I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Did you say anything?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Yes. No. Goodbye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Goodwin. Goodwin OPENS the note. The letterhead, CHARLES VAN DOREN Scrawled beneath: It was a pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.text: You Goodwin?
