dialogues.text: Goodwin smokes a cigar in bed, cradles the PHONE on his shoulder. Sandra does the crossword at home in Georgetown

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: What if I told you ‘21° was vigged?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: ‘21’ is like wrestling?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: That’s what that grand jury was about. Herbert Stempel admits that they gave him the answers in advance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: That’s unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: And when they wanted him to lose, they made him take a dive.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: What about Van Doren?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I met him today. Him and his father. It turns out--

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Did you ask him if he’s getting the answers?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: O£ course I asked him. You're not listening.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: It turns out Clark Byse is an old family friend.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: -Who?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: My old Contracts professor at Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t make sense that you'd make one guy take a dive and not give the other guy the answers.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You sound like Stempel. SANDRA. What makes you think van Doren didn't get the answers?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Sandra--why would somebody like Charles Van Doren jeopardize everything he has for a quiz show? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Those good-looking guys are always bullshit artists.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what I'm onto here? I’m going after some of the biggest institutions in the country! Me, Dick Goodwin--the former bard of the Fayetteville Kiwanis--

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You smoking in the bed? Goodwin draws deep. Grins ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I’m having the time of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbie brushes his teeth in the bathroom. Inside, Toby tu down the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You never told me you got the ~answers,.Herb.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Of course they gave me the answers. I mean, not very many answers. I’m sure I mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It’s not a thing you ‘mention’. What else did you do that you didn’t ‘mention’?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: What, are you gonna start on me, too? The man came here, he sat in our kitchen and he said, ‘How'd you like to make $25,000’? I don’t know any man in America who'd turn that down.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That's not the point. Herbie enters the bedroom, brandishing his toothbrush. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Let me tell you about honest. You know what my father used to tell me? ‘Work hard and you'll get ahead’. Was that honest? Look at Geritol--’Geritol cures tired blood’ --and I’m the one who's supposed te be ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You never said you were getting the answers.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Let them believe whatever they want. What do I care? What do I care if a bunch of saps--

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (right back) I was one of the saps, Herbert.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: For the first time, he realizes what he did to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The set is-dark. Goodwin climbs ‘into -an ctsolation boot a set of headphones. Looks out through the Plexiglas, out the empty seats, the podium where Barry stands...

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Well, gee, Jack. Hmmm. Ty Cobb, for starters. (beat) Would Honus Wagner be the next? (beat) Most base hits...Something makes me want to say Tris Speaker-- An NBC PAGE knocks at the door, startling Goodwin.

dialogues.speaker: NBC PAGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Enright will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DAY. ENRIGHT’S OFFICE. Goodwin enters. An angry Enright confronts him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Did you see the paper this morning? He hands him the Daily News. A large PHOTOGRAPH of Goodwin--snapped last night at the hotel--beneath the hea

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I will not have my show--what we've accomplished for the cause of education--slandered like this in the tabloids.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I assure you, I had nothing to do with this. ‘ENRIGHT Fix? The questions on ‘21’ are certified by the Encyclopedia Britannica! They‘re kept under lock and key in a bank vault!

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Notwithstanding the bank vault, Mr. Enright, Herbert Stempel swears the show is rigged.

dialogues.speaker: . ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: It would take a real individualist to believe Herb Stempel. Does he have any concrete evidence? Does it make any sense that a man would implicate himself like this?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve only just--

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s not even logical. Do you know how the show works? If I made him take a dive, I'd have to give the answers to Charles Van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Not necessarily.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Charles Van Dorent With his background? I think if you even suggested a scheme like that he’d punch you in the nose.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: With my nose he could hardly miss.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Mr. Goodwin, I'd rather not share this with anyone, but it seems like there’s no other way.

dialogues.speaker: A TAPE RECORDER
dialogues.text: Sits on the coffee table. Enright hits "PLAY",

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I need that money, Dant I need that panel show! That big blond putz 1s on the cover of Time and I can’t even make the top fucking 42 for a fucking panel show? “ENRIGHT (0.C.) I think it’s important that you see an analyst, Herb, for the - intensive psychiatric care we both know you need.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I'm going to the D.A. And the newspapers. I’m gonna tell the world that ‘21’ is nothing but a fraud. “ENRIGHT {0.C.) This is a crude blackmail attempt that will never succeed. You know that I’ve always been scrupulously honest with you. .

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I'm bringing you down with me, you lousy lying prick--you and Charles Van fucking Doren. Enright stops the tape. Shakes his head...

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand--he needed money?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Gambling. And that’s the least of it. I trust you’ll keep this between us--given Herb’s medical condition... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medical condition? Enright goes to his desk. Opens the top drawer, returns w sheaf of BILLS. Goodwin examines them.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I’ve been paying his psychiatrist's bills. A man like Herb, no longer in the public eye--television‘’s like a monkey on his back. Needless to say, I feel responsible.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Five sessions a week?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not so bad that he needs to be institutionalized... Enright ushers Goodwin to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: My theory, Dick, is that Herb is so angry with himself for losing, so guilt-ridden, that he has projected that enormous guilt onto the person of Charles Van Doren--blames him for his - downfall. Whereas the real ~-downfall of: Herbert: Stempel has always been, regrettably... Herbert Stempel.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Do you worry about Van Doren? Someday when he’s not in the public eye--

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: He's far less neurotic than Herbie, 73 INT. DAY. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE. An ANALYST sits in a cool, dimly-lit room. Charlie lies o couch alongside him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: --:I keep having this dream. I open up my billfold, and there’s a $20 bill there. And I take it out, and close the billfold, and when I open the billfold again, there’s another $20 bill. And it’s pleasurable at first. But then T want it to stop, and I can‘t. Do you have any idea what that might mean? (a long beat} You sound just like my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin rings the bell. Toby answers, WORRY on her brow.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Hello. Is Herb around? (reacting) What's the matter? Lester emerges from the shadows. With a vivid BLACK EYE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbie RAGES outside a neighbor’s home. A CROWD gathered him.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Come on, you son of a bitch! Take responsibility for your degenerate son. The NEIGHBOR, a brute in an undershirt, appears at the up window. Scratches under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Drop dead. He slams the window shut.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: ‘Drop dead’. That’s very . articulate. (gesturing) Darwin disproved, ladies and gentlemen! The window opens. The Neighbor leans out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: (sneering) ‘Marty’! ‘Marty’!

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: fights through the crowd. Herbie hustles up to the doorbe Leans on it. Hustles back down and resumes his siege.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You think you can just move into this neighborhood and launch a pogrom?

dialogues.speaker: GCODWIN
dialogues.text: Herb, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: What? {sees Goodwin) Hey! You know who’s here? The United States Congress is here!

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Would you tell me what happened?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Get up there. Subpoena him, that son of a bitch. Herbie shoves Goodwin toward the door. “~“THE WINDOW “OPENS and the Neighbor emerges again.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Say hello to the United States Congress, pytz.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Listen, asshole, you have--

dialogues.speaker: HIS TOUPEE
dialogues.text: as it falls off, lands softly. Herbie runs, GRABS it.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Rapunzel!

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Leave that alone!

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Come down and get it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Herbie plants the toupee firmly on his own head.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEIGHBOR DISAPPEARS
dialogues.text: from the window...Heading down...Herbie turns to Goodwin.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Wait’ll he discovers the wrath of the American people as delivered by their elected vepresentatives.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: What happened to Lester?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Did you see? Did you see what his son did to my son?

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR OPENS
dialogues.text: and the Neighbor emerges.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Gimme it back.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: His son called my son a kike, okay? I don't have to take that. In my own neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son takes it back. I’m calling you a kike.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: A kike? You who couldn’t spell kike are calling me kike?

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: I call and am calling you kike.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: {to Goodwin) Go ahead. Subpoena him.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Will you please stop?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Subpoena him! Go ahead! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Herbie shoves Goodwin toward the Neighber. The Neighbor s him back. Goodwin staggers, regains his balance. The Neig grabs at the toupee. A tug of war... HERBIE . Do you knew whe this is?

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Another fucking kike. Goodwin rears...Balls his fist...

dialogues.speaker: SMACKS THE NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: The Neighbor staggers back...Then VOLLEYS back with a lef hook...Herbie jumps him. Others jump in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morose, Goodwin holds an icebag on his head. Elated, Herb holds a steak on his eye.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: That was some shot you gave him. I can even forgive you for not giving him the subpoena.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: (ironic) I’m glad I could help out.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Did you see that one I gave him? That hook?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I may have missed it.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You think he has maybe some ringing in his ear? He’1l be answering the phone for a week. (gesturing) ‘Hello?’ ‘Hello?’ Guys like you and me--he’s never seen guys like you and me.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Herb...I spoke to Dan Enright. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: That's a big waste of time. When are you gonna talk to Van Doren? You owe me, you know. Who do you think tipped the Daily News? Goodwin starts to say something. Decides against it.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Enright--what, did he play that tape for you? He tried to scare me off with that, that prick. Listen to me--like I’m shocked. If the man had one ounce of ethics they‘d throw him out of the Producer’s union.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He implied that he might leak it to the press.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: That’d be just like him--to wait till I'm forgotten and then smear me back into the public eye.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Is there anyone who can corroborate your story? Any concrete evidence? “HERBIE Just talk to Van Doren. WASPs--they can’t even help it, they‘re congenital liars. Ask Van Doren what day it is and he'll lie to you just for practice.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: This isn‘t about Van Doren, Herb.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You think it isn’t, but it is. Trust me. Go. Enough with the ice. Go up to Columbia--I’m sure he’s there right now. Gol Herbie grabs the ice bag out of Goodwin's hand, throws it sink. PULLS him by the shirt up out of his chair. Goodwin Knocks Herbie’s hand away.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Cut it out! Stop. Just stop. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Don’t think I don’t see what youre doing. You're going to uuild this great case--against me. A pile of evidence, an army of witnesses--yes, indeed, Herb Stempel got the answers. And meanwhile you and Van Doren are off giving each other the secret Ivy League handshake.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You didn’t say those things?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I fell for the same bullshit, okay? I thought I had some stake in the system.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He’s not paying your psychiatrist’s bills?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute--who do you believe here?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I believe you, Herb. But frankly, you're a lousy witness. Herbie, deflated, ‘looks ‘out ‘the -window... INT. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: It’s gonna change, you know. Magnetism. What's attractive. What’s sexy. What’s ‘in’. You think I’m wrong? I’m never wrong--that’s my curse. Every movie, every Magazine, it’s gonna be short, annoying Jewish guys with big noses and a lot of hair on their backs. And Italians. You think I’m kidding? Guys like you and me--we’re just ahead of our time.

dialogues.speaker: NEC.
dialogues.text: Freedman hands Charlie a MANILA ENVELOPE with the answers (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Here you go, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I was thinking, Al--if it’s okay--I was thinking that I'd prefer it from now on if you just give me the questions. And then I could look up the answers on my own.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Just give you the questions.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then I look up the answers myself. It’s, don’t you think--well, less egregious? Freedman takes the envelope back.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Took the words right out of my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Charlie heads down the hall. Runs into Goodwin.as he em Erom a “STORAGE ROOM, his arms laden with BOXES- -filled KINESCOPES and files. Two JANITORS follow with more boxes

dialogues.speaker: IE
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Charlie. (off boxes) Nothing like a subpoena. Goodwin continues down the hall. Charlie broods a beat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (after him) Hey! See you tomorrow!  19 80 89. INT. LATER. HOTEL ROOM. Goodwin watches a KINESCOPE on the wall. An old "21" epis 16mm PROJECTOR whirs on a table. File boxes and film cans around the room.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: They want me to think Herbie’s crazy. He's no more crazy than my Uncle Harold.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Your Uncle Harold's crazy, Dick. He made a pass at me at our wedding.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Then why is it? Why is it I still believe him?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I know what your mother would say.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You take after your Uncle Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tired Goodwin boxes a KINESCOPE. Threads a new one thro projector. Snaps it ON.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WALL
dialogues.text: as the projector clickety-clacks and Goodwin adjusts the focus--Stempel faces JAMES SNODGRASS, a Greenwich Village in his late 20s. Barry introduces him.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: And James Snodgrass--you're an artist by profession?

dialogues.speaker: SNODGRASS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: That’s right, Jack. A painter.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Well, fellows--what do you say? Let‘’s play ‘21°! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON- -GOODWIN
dialogues.text: as he pours himself a cup of coffee. Boxes of FILES stack around the room.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WALL
dialogues.text: as Barry launches into his first question.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Jim, I‘1l read you lines from four of America’s greatest poets, First, ‘I hear America singing--the very carols I hear’.

dialogues.speaker: SNODGRASS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: That would be Walt Whitman.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: That’s right. Second: ‘I shot an arrow in the air...‘

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN WATCHES
dialogues.text: rubs his tired eyes. Pours himself more COFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Finally, ‘Hope is the thing with feathers--that perches in the soul’.

dialogues.speaker: SNODGRASS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ‘Hope is the thing with feathers--that perches in the soul’.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Would you like more time?

dialogues.speaker: SNODGRASS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: No. That’s Emily Dickinson.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I’m--. (doubletake) Emily Dickinson?

dialogues.speaker: SNODGRASS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: She’s one of my favorite poets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he sees the doubletake. Sits up and takes notice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Ho! Well, yes! All right, Jim--you couldn’t get off to a better start-- Goodwin fumbles with the Projector. REWINDS the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily Dickinson.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I‘m--. (doubletake) Emily Dickinson?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON- -GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Excited now, he rewinds the film again.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C,)
dialogues.text: I‘m--. (doubletake) Emily Dickinson?

dialogues.speaker: SNODGRASS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: She’s one of my favorite poets. Goodwin grabs the phone. Dials “Information”.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I need an address for a James Snodgrass. Try Greenwich Village.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Ho! Well. yes! All right, Jim--you’re off to a veritable flying start, and we'll get back to you after this word about another of our fine products.

dialogues.text: Goodwin and Charlie zoom up Park Avenue, top down, hair w in the summer wind.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Guys like you and me, Dick--the way American society is today--it’s so hard to find a way to stand out. Nothing seems to be enough. The irony is, I sometimes think a volume of Keats and a room full of freshmen is all I really need. Charlie drives a beat. Then turns te Goodwin with a smile

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So what do you think of the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: revealing Charlie’s brand-new RED MERCEDES 190--the one G saw earlier. A traffic light turns RED as Charlie BLASTS it... :

dialogues.text: as it‘s thrown into the middle of a table. A thunderhead tobacco smoke. Goodwin Plays SEVEN-CARD STUD with Charlie four well-bred WASP buddies: FRED, GENE, JACK, and TREY.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: «..Fold.

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: Fold.

dialogues.text: (to Trey) Nice home you have here.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Raise a dollar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’d better watch out, Fred. Dick’s one of the brightest young lawyers down in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Great. All my money already goes to Washington.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’m out.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Taxes--it’s nothing but organized theft.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: {correcting him) Property.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: "Property is theft’--I believe that’s the iscus classicus. From Proudhon.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: {to Fred) I warned you.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Great. Another one. The betting concludes... .Jack @eals the next round...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (looks at cards) What‘re you working on there, Charlie? Charlie looks at his cards, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Raise five dollars. Goodwin and Charlie lock gazes. Goodwin throws in another Fred thinks, throws in another five.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I'd love to know what you have under there, Charlie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack deals another round...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The truth has its price.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Everything has its Price.

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: So where'd you prep, Dick? Silence. They all look at Goodwin. He STAMMERS...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dick’s up here on a witchhunt. He thinks ‘21’ is fixed, and I’m getting the answers beforehand.

dialogues.speaker: _ GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Are you? Everyone starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Try him.

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: (mimics Charlie) I’ll take nine, nine points.

dialogues.text: Name the first five Vice Presidents,

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let’s see. John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, Aaron Burr, George Clinton, and Elbridge Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARL.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Joseph Belgium. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: It's Baudouin, King Baudouin.

dialogues.text: Bo who?

dialogues.text: The night Lincoln was shot- -who was the doctor at his deathbed, who embalmed him, and who was the detective on the case?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Could we have a card game here? It‘s bad enough my wife makes me watch this bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The detective was Clarvoe, John Alexander Clarvoe...James Hall was the doctor. And he was embalmed --who embalmed him? Cattell, Henry or Harry--Henry Cattell embalmed him.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: And then he got murdered with estate taxes.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I’m impressed. You're not impressed? Charlie smiles at Goodwin. Takes out his wallet. Pulls ou FIFTY-DOLLAR BILL. Slides it onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (folding) Now I'm impressed.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Dick--call him. Goedwin leoks at Charlie. Looks at the fifty.

dialogues.speaker: . IE

dialogues.text: a2 CONTINUED: (4) . GocDwIN Too rich for my blood.

dialogues.text: Try Geritol,

dialogues.text: Sandwich time. Everyone heads to the kitchen, leaving Goodwin and Charli Fred slaps Goodwin on the back.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (to Goodwin) ‘Property is theft’ - -maybe we should investigate you. Charlie smiles enigmatically as he rakes in the money... looks Charlie in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: " GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I know you’re lying.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Bluffing’, Dick--the term is ‘bluffing’.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Charlie...I know you're lying. They exchange a long look.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry you feel that way, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin talks on the phone to Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I hope you‘re satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I thought you had something.

dialogues.speaker: . GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He knows I have something, and he still denied it. Now what does that tell you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: What? SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Stempel aot the answers because were trying to create Van Doren. Then they got the real van Doren. Stempel is Frankenstein.

dialogues.speaker: . SANDRA
dialogues.text: It just doesn’t make any sense.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: That's the last poker game I get invited to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The frantic AUDIENCE throngs toward the doors, held by struggling USHERS. Goodwin fights toward the door...

dialogues.speaker: USHER
dialogues.text: The hell with it--let ‘em in. The Ushers drop the ropes...The crowd SURGES forward, car Goodwin along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An atmosphere ELECTRIC with anticipation. TECHNICIANS adj lights, test microphones. The ORCHESTRA tunes up. VIVIENNE NEARING, 30s, the attractive CHALLENGER, sits ne tearing a Kleenex. Barry approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Nearing? I’m Jack Barry. Welcome aboard. She jumps up. The pieces of Kleenex SCATTER. Barry kneels pick them up. A MAKE-UP ARTIST approaches Mrs. Nearing.

dialogues.speaker: . MAKE-UP ARTIST
dialogues.text: You're a little shiny on the monitor, ma‘am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: While the Make-Up Artist dabs with a powder puff, Barry l Mrs. Nearing’s skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appalled, Enright watches Barry on the MONITOR. Charlie p Freedman leans back on a swivel chair.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: +--He’s bluffing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘I know you’re lying‘. Those were his words.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: I grew up’with guys like him. He‘s a poodzh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He may be a noodzh, but he was also first in his class at Harvard Law School, Freedman dismisses this with a masturbating gesture.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Will you please stop that?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Charlie, you have to look at this analytically. We know he's spoken to Stempel. At best he’s found another contestant who’s told him a similar story.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How many people did you give the answers to?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: That‘s not the point.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I want to know. Did anybody play this: game straight?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: We have 37 contestants who swore their innocence to the grand jury. (more) (CONTINUED)
ENRIGHT (Cont'd) If they change that story, they’d go to jail for perjury.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Maybe I should just tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You'll set back education in this country 50 years! Do you want that blood on your hands?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I just had no idea it would go this far.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Charlie, the only people who can implicate you directly are all in this room. Think about that.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dan. (to Charlie) you think that noodzh is gonna get me to talk?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. I suppose you're right.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: They could kill me, I wouldn’t talk. They could submit me to any kind of torture...ah...ah...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (helpfully) The rack.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: They could put me on the rack.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The Iron Maiden,

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The bastinado. The . Boiling in oil. Running the gauntlet... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: I’m not telling them a fucking thing. Correct me, Dan, if I’m wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You‘re Charles Van Doren. Remember that. It’s their word against yours.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: They took a vote in this country--they’d put you on the dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh great.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: There’s no concrete evidence. No tapes. Nothing in writing.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: Plus what did you do wrong? Everybody knows the magician don’t saw the lady in half.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s hardly the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: It’s entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: IT am a college professor! A KNOCK, and an NBC PAGE enters.

dialogues.text: They need the professor in makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbie watches ‘21' with two BARFLIES.

dialogues.speaker: . ANNOUNCER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: +..returning with $143,000, from New York City, Charles Van Doren! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Correct for eight points!
