dialogues.text: Dorothy wrings her hands beside her bored husband.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: -.-the P-40, the P-47, the P-S1, the B-24, the B-25 and the B-26. Give me the nicknames that the Air Force gave to these planes.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Why, that’s much harder than the question they asked that woman--and hers was ten points. Do you know the names of those Planes?

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Of course not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Who would know the names of those Planes? He’s not the Secretary of Defense.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 91 INT. SAME TIME. ENRIGHT’S OFFICE. Enright gestures to a seat, closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Mr. Goodwin, you're a very disruptive young man.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Do you remember James Snodgrass? He was a contestant on your show.

dialogues.speaker: " ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: A bohemian type, wasn’t he? Al digs these people up. I don’t know where he finds them.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: ‘Hope is the thing with feathers- That perches in the soul--'?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Thanks for the fortune--where‘s the cookie?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: That’s the first line of a poem by Emily Dickinson. You told James Snodgrass to identify the author, incorrectly, as Ralph Waldo Emerson.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Mr. Goodwin--between Herb and now the ravings of this Greenwich Village beatnik: -

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He‘’s a beatnik? Why? Because he’s not Charles van Doren?

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: You’re damn right he’s not Charles Van Doren. {more) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARFLY
dialogues.text: I got one for you. Name the guy that lost to van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: BARFLY
dialogues.text: Gee. I don’t remember. Who the hell was thac?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TELEVISION
dialogues.text: as the show begins...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Well, Charlie, what do you think of Mrs. Nearing?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: She’s quite terrifying. ’ BARRY (0.C.) Quite a bean inside that pretty head, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON- -HERBIE
dialogues.text: as he starts to THRILL...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Goodwin got something. He's taking a dive. Herbie hustles to a PHONE BOOTH in back. Dials.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: {to phone) I have a bet for you.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 88 INT. SAME TIME. ‘21° SET. Freedman and Enright watch Charlie on the monitors.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: You don’t think Charlie’d--you don’t think he'd blow the whole thing, do you? Get Garroway.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ENRIGHT (Cont'd) (resuming) Without a single shrea of concrete evidence-- these unsubstantiated crackpot allegations-- Goodwin reaches into his jacket pocket. Pulls our

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Inside this envelope are all the questions James Snodgrass was asked on ‘21’. What’s odd is that he appeared on the show on May 13th. And he mailed this letter to himself on May llth. Registered mail. Now I’d say that’s pretty goddam concrete. Enright draws on his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: I don’t suppose you'd be interested in your own panel show. Goodwin gets up. Moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Think about testifying against the network.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: What about Van Doren? You den‘t have anything on van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: It’s over, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: ENRIGHT
dialogues.text: Never underestimate the American public.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 92 INT. LATER. '21° SET. Barry talks to camera.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: _--AS we enter our final round, Mrs. (more) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BARRY (Cont’d) Nearing leads by a score of 20 fo 16. It is the moment of truth, as it were, for Professor Charles Van Doren...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ISOLATION BOOTH
dialogues.text: Charlie alone with the sound of his own breathing, his pu loud in his ears...

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON-
dialogues.text: as he continues...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: -+.after a record-breaking 14 weeks...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Charlie looks out from his plexiglas cage. His watch TICKING...His heart pounds louder...WHAM! WHAM! WHAM!

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON-
dialogues.text: as he hits a button...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Nearing?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NEARING
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: . BARRY
dialogues.text: We're going to let you listen in on this last round.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BOOTH
dialogues.text: as the noise in Charlie’s head CRESCENDOES, breath roarin heartbeat like tympani...The Intercom CRACKLES on.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: The category is royalty.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Royalty. Well, let‘s see. I'll take five, five points. That would get me to 21.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BALCONY
dialogues.text: Goodwin arrives. Takes his seat in the audience... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (reading) Name the Kings of the following countries: Norway, Sweden, Belgium, and Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Could I take the third Part last?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NEARING
dialogues.text: listens nervously in her booth...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Norway, that would be Haakon, King Haakon.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: " CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sweden--that’s Gustavus.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: The King of Iraq?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I believe that’s his grandfather who's portrayed in that wonderful book, ‘The Seven Pillars of Wisdom’. (beat) Faisal! King Faisal.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: And Belgium?

dialogues.speaker: TIME. ACROSS THE COUNTRY.
dialogues.text: FAMILIES crowd anxiously around the TV...NUNS tug at thei rosaries..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People on

dialogues.speaker: TIME. MOVIE THEATER.
dialogues.text: the ‘edge of their seats...  95 96 97 98 99 107. INT. SAME TIME. PARK AVENUE. Charlie‘s buddies and their wives, frozen in anticipation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra eats Chinese food on the bed. Lifting a shrimp to mouth with her chopsticks, she FREEZES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign reads: “CONSULATE OF BELGIUM"

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: The STAFF of the Belgian consulate crowd around a small T

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Belgium...Belgium... INT. NIGHT. CONTROL ROOM. A pensive Enright returns. Freedman stares at the monitor

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It seems like an easy one...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Would you like more time?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: If I could, please.

dialogues.speaker: FREEDMAN
dialogues.text: That son of a bitch--he’s gonna dump it. The “suspense" music BUILDS... INT. NIGHT. SPONSOR’ S APARTMENT. The Sponsor and Kintner look at each other...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 100 201 102 103 108. INT. SAME TIME. BAR. Herbie watches at the bar, EDGY...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NIGHT. ‘21° ser, Charlie tucked inside himself...Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: watches from the balcony...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Leopold?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: No. I’m sorry. It’s Baudouin, King Baudouin. The audience GASPS. Charlie folds--like he’s been gutshot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his face turned away from the audience. As he SMILES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he knows...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SAME TIME. SPONSOR‘’S HOME. The Sponsor turns to Kintner.

dialogues.speaker: SPONSOR
dialogues.text: How the hell did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trey turns to the others.

dialogues.speaker: TREY
dialogues.text: How could he miss that? Remember? I asked him that the other night--at the poker game. CUT To:  104 INT. SAME TIME. VAN DOREN HOME.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Nearing, you are our new champion with $8,000! Dorothy, crestfallen, turns off the Tv. Turns to The Prof Who’s sound ASLEEP. She NUDGES him awake

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: What? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Charlie lost.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Oh. (beat) What was the question?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Who's the King of Belgium. The Professor gets ‘up.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Who cares who the King of Belgium is besides the Queen of Belgium?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: That isn’t the point.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Some overbred bore with a Hapsburg lip. You want a glass of milk?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Mark Van Doren- -

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Mother, please--it's a quiz show. It’s not as if it were something that really mattered.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 105 INT. SAME TIME. ‘21’ SET. As Mrs. Nearing and Charlie approach the lectern, Barry n someone in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: . BARRY
dialogues.text: Ho! Who is that over there in our studio audience? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: A SPOTLIGHT
dialogues.text: Sweeps over the audience. Lands on DAVE GARROWAY.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Is that Dave Garroway? Dave Garroway of the NBC Today Show, ladies and gentlemen! Charlie, PUZZLED, looks out toward the audience.

dialogues.speaker: THE APPLAUSE SIGN
dialogues.text: Spurs a cheer as Garroway bounces up onto the Stage...Sha hands with Barry and Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: GARROWAY
dialogues.text: Charlie--I'1l admit this has all happened rather suddenly, but--you‘ve become like a friend, a wonderful visitor to millions of homes all across America.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dave. I just think I’m going to enjoy some peace and quiet now, and a chance to get back to my books- -

dialogues.speaker: GARROWAY
dialogues.text: We at the NBC Today Show would like you to be our special cultural correspondent - -our Ambassador from the land of culture and learning to the people and the schoolchildren of America... CHARLIE . Well, I hope you’re not firing the monkey.

dialogues.speaker: GARROWAY
dialogues.text: -+-at a salary of $50,000 a year. He takes out a CONTRACT with a flourish. Charlie gapes at

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: (mutters) . Turn it down--you don’t need it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARROWAY
dialogues.text: It's the world's biggest classroom, Professor. Just sign on the dotted line. Garroway hands Charlie a pen. Charlie takes it. And SIGNS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOOKIE, tough, 40s, counts out a stack of bills.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Put them all the same way. So they're facing the same way. The Bookie glowers at Herbie. Reverses the bill. Continue

dialogues.speaker: BOOKIE
dialogues.text: You knew something, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: No. It was, you know, a hunch--it was just a hunch.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKIE
dialogues.text: Just a hunch. A $10,000 hunch.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Don’t blame me. You want to break somebody's legs, break Van Doren’s legs. (beat) I mean, you know, not--maybe one leg. The Bookie finishes counting. Hands Herbie the cash.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 107 EXT. MORNING. CHARLIE'’S TOWNHOUSE. Goodwin rings the doorbell. Charlie answers in a bathrobe

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Dick. Would you like to come in?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 108 INT. MORNING. CHARLIE’S TOWNHOUSE. Charlie and Goodwin enter the living room. No furniture. full of books, yet to be unpacked. And a gigantic TELEVIS

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Excuse the robe. Last night was the first decent night’s sleep I’ve had in months.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Nice place you have here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I haven’t had the chance to furnish it.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: {off television) Just the essentials.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: God knows when I’11 get to this now, with this Today Show--did you watch last night?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Congratulations. ‘The world’s biggest classroom’.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s the world’s biggest something. Would you like a cup of coffee? Charlie goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Just like Herbie. Charlie ducks back out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: ‘King Baudouin’. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh. That. You know, apparently the Belgian Consulate has formally protested my ignorance. Charlie returns to the kitchen. Makes two cups of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I was just thinking it’s juste like Herbie. You lost on one you knew.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Charlie STOPS. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How do you like it, Dick? you seem like a black coffee man. Goodwin enters. Charlie hands him a cup cf coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: The other night, Charlie. At the poker game. Trey asked you to name the King of Belgium and you nailed it. You even spelled it right.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, dear--you know, you're right! How could that’ve slipped my mind?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: For Chrissakes, Charlie--I’m not after you. I‘m not gonna call you to testify. I’m even glad that a real intellectual made some money off this crazy scheme. I just want to hear you say it. It didn’t ‘slip your mind’ - -you took a dive. Charlie takes his coffee cup. Flees into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You people are so persistent. Goodwin follows after him.

dialogues.speaker: . GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Why the hell did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Please, Dick--I’m Charles van Doren, I can‘t-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You'll feel better. For yourself--just admit it to one other person. Charlie looks at Goodwin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know, Dick, the poets used to say the stag loves the hunter who kills it. Goodwin gives up. Puts his coffee cup on the Tv.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. If anybody should ask you about the quiz shows--don‘t make any kind of a public statement. Don’t hold a press conference. Because then T’1l have to call you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Dick. Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Charlie. Goodwin moves to the door. Charlie calls to hin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you ever need a place to stay when you’re in New York--well, I’m all alone here.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I’ve hunted stag, Charlie, with my uncle, up in Maine. I don’t think there‘s much affection either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin sits under the peacock. Checks his watch. Gets up

dialogues.speaker: . SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Kintner apologizes, he’s unavailable. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I’m going back to Washington today. He can reach me at the committee.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: He’ll know what this is in reference to?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Tell him to read the Papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spinning headlines: Daily News: HOUSE SIFTS TV QUIZ

dialogues.speaker: FIX
dialogues.text: World-Telegram: THE $64,000

dialogues.speaker: ANSWER
dialogues.text: Journal-American: QUIZ HEARINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTER #1 talks on the phone te his editor.

dialogues.speaker: . REPORTER
dialogues.text: .-:Stempel. (covers phone) Is it Stempel E-L or L-E? (to phone) I think it’s E-L. Three other REPORTERS surround Herbie. Toby pours coffee. of Lester drumming inside. The doorbell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You know, it's very amusing to me that all you bums are knocking on my door now. I gave you this story six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: . REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Stempel, you have any baby pictures of Herb we could use? The doorbell rings again. Toby EXITS toward the door...

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: {to Herbie) Do you think you could ask the kid to stop for five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you interview him? Lester, L-E-S-T-E-R. It’s a good human interest angle.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How'd all this starr?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I was babysitting for my son, Enright came to see me. He sat tight in that kitchen and he said, ‘How'd you like to make $25,000?’ And I said, ‘Who wouldn't?’ Toby returns with REPORTER #S.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How’s it feel to be the center of all this attention?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Get in line.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: {reading) © ‘How'd you like to make $25,000?° And you said, ‘Who wouldn’t?’ Toby senses the mood changing... She exits.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go look for the baby pictures.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: In retrospect--I mean, look at Van Doren--I should’ve held cut for a lot more.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: What does Van Doren have to do with it? You prostituted your name, your intellectual ability, for money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You're missing the story.

dialogues.speaker: REFORTER
dialogues.text: You pulled a con job on the American people.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: So did he, dope. So did Charles Van Doren, but you know what? I got him. I nailed him. That's your story. .

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Can you prove it?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I don't have to prove it anymore. That goddam pious hypocrite--let‘s see him lie to the United States Congress.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: I just spoke to the committee. They’re not calling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin reads the paper. Sandra moves around the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You‘re gonna do a quiz show hearing without Charles van Deren?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Van Doren‘’s story is the same as Herbie’s, the same as Snodgrass.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: He admits it?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I‘m saying even if he admits it, he doesn’t add anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’1ll you do when he makes a statement proclaiming his innocence? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1il

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He's not going to do that.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You‘re going to look like a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Why would he do thar? r told him to keep his mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: T still don’t know why he’s not going to testify.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I just told you why. The hearings are circumscribed by legislative purpose. The legislative purpose is to reform television, not to reform Charles Van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Don‘t patronize me.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I wouldn't patronize you if you'd pay attention. It’s the same as the and cases, when I was at The Court.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: If you don’t want to answer, just don’t answer. Don't give me a lot ef legal bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: GOCDWIN
dialogues.text: I don’t see any need to drag the man into the spotlight and tidicule him.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You're dragging Herb Stempel into the spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Herbie doesn’t need to be dragged into the spotlight, believe me. ™ SANDRA Nobody forced Van Doren to go in front of 50 million people either. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: At least he has the good sense to keep his mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Good sense or good breeding?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Oh, for crying out loud. He made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You know, Dick, you're ten times the guy Charles Van Doren is, ten times the brain, ten times the human being, and meanwhile : the one bending over backwards for him. You’re like the Uncle Tom of the Jews.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I’m glad it’s so easy for you to destroy a man’s life. I‘ll keep it in mind.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Quiz show hearings without Van Doren--it’s like doing ‘Hamlet without Hamlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie arrives with his parents in tow. The MAITRE D’ fa over Charlie. MAITRE D’ Welcome, Professor van Doren! (to Waiter) Professor Van Doren’s table. (to The Professor) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I’m also Professor Van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three tonight. The Professor scowls as the Maitre D’ ushers them inside. CUT To:  120. 113° INT. LATER. LE crroug. Charlie, Dorothy and The Professor sit over their meal.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Look at your plate, Charlie--you’re hardly eating. It’s as bad as when you were on that quiz show. You'd come over for dinner and just push a pea around your plate.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Maybe it was your cooking.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: ‘How ill white hairs become a fool and jester!’

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: ‘QO curse of marriage! That we can call these delicate creatures ours’.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Othello. Dorothy cuts off a piece of veal from her plate. Gestures Professor.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Take some of this veal, Professor. I can’t finish this. (resuming) Not that we saw you that often. I don’t think we had dinner together three times in all the months you were on that show.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Uneasy lies the head that wears the crown’.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: ‘Some rise by sin, and some by virtue fall’.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: - ‘What! must I hold a candle to my shames?°

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mother, pass the pepper.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: ‘O! what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily do, not knowing what they do!’

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: fu ing. ‘I ama man more sinned against than sinning’.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Lear. ‘The wheel is come full circle’.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Also Lear. ‘What’s gone and what’s past help/ Should be past grief’.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Is something going on?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s just a game, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Oh! Professor! Did you remember to give Charlie that letter?

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. You got a letter sent to you up in Cornwall--it was addressed to Professor Van Doren, I opened it by mistake. The Professor pulls out an envelope. Hands it to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: It’s probably another one of those mash notes. Read it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: It‘s personal.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Especially if it's personal. As Charlie reads, he starts to TREMBLE with rage... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (reads aloud) Dear Professor Van Doren, I am @ great admirer of yours. The only way you will be able to live with yourself is to admit what you did--openly, clearly, and truly--as painful as that might be. You must remember that you are a Van Doren. Signed, A Friend.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Admit what? What’s he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: {to the Professor) You wrote this, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: " THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (blank) It was in the mail.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you have something to say to me, why don’t you just say it, goddamit!

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you admit what you’re really thinking--that you’re thrilled!

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I will not sit here while you make a scene in front of your mother.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, come off it, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you're talking about, Charlie--it was in the mailbox!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: {right back) There’s no goddam postmark!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charlie storms out. patrons and waiters gape at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bedroom, Toby packs a bag for Herbie. He sits en t tadiator, broods out the window, through the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: How long are you gonna be gone? Just overnight?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Pack me two nights just in case. After I tell my story--you never know--Eisenhower might want to see me. She lays neckties out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Which suit do you want?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: The sharkskin. Not that tie--the television tie.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You sure you're doing the right thing?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Of course I’m doing the cight thing.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I just hope everyone doesn’t hate you.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: They‘re not gonna hate me.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Herbie, you're gonna go up there in front of 50 million people and tell them they’re so stupid they could watch that show week after week and never for a second think you were pulling something on them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: They’re not gonna hate me--I’m telling the truth!

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m your wife that loves you and I feel like a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do--am I supposed to just take it and take it and take it? They made me lose on ‘Marty’. I'm supposed to take it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: T just don’t know what you‘re gonna accomplish. ’ HERBIE I‘ll tell you what. I’m going down to Washington and if I do nothing else I will convince them that Herbert Stempel knows what won the goddam Academy Award for Best goddam Picture of 1955. Toby returns to packing the bags.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Where’d you go with the car today?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Connecticut. I had to drop something off.

dialogues.speaker: A MOB OF REPORTERS
dialogues.text: crowd outside, jostle against the NBC SECURITY GUARDS bar the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHOTOGRAPHERS load their cameras.

dialogues.speaker: TIME. STAGE.
dialogues.text: Charlie wraps up his segment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -+-‘"Beauty is truth, truth beauty--that is all Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know" .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garroway sits with J. Fred Muggs. who SQUAWKS, scratches.

dialogues.speaker: GARROWAY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Charles van Doren, for those timeless sentiments. Now for a word from Ex-Lax. Charlie tears off his lavolier, heads for the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie goes to see Freedman. His SECRETARY on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Freedman’s office. Would you hold? (punching button) I'm sorry, he’s unavailable... {covering phone) Mr. Van Doren--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’s Al? Is he in? Before she can stop him, he opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE FREEDMAN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: No photos. No papers. CLEANED OUT. The window is opened, curtain blows EERILY...The Secretary follows inside.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: He’s gone, Mr. Van Doren, he‘s--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, gone? He’s gone home?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: He’s gone to Mexico. Charlie blinks. He leans out the window... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLIE‘’S POV The crowd of REPORTERS outside...He turns to the Secretar

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Is there a back way out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks furtively up the back hallway. Climbs into SERVICE ELEVATOR, rides down. Suddenly, it STOPS. Charlie the button. Then again. Like a Morse key now...Then

dialogues.speaker: THE DOORS OPEN
dialogues.text: A man climbs in...It’s Kintner.

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: Charlie, I’m the President of NaC. I think it's time we met. He presses a button. They ride down. Kintner hands him a of PAPER. Charlie reads it.

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: Our legal department Prepared this for you. You declare your complete innocence of any wrongdoing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pointing) There’s a split infinitive here in the second Paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: Television is a public trust. We can’t afford to have even a hint of scandal in our company.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s just that--well, Dick Goodwin, he suggested: -

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dick Goodwin. With the Committee. He suggested that I not say anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . KINTNER
dialogues.text: This is a time when we all need to pull together. Haven't we been good to you, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, absolutely. It’s just that--

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t want your family to think you're involved in this whole mess, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONGRESSMEN arrayed in a leng arc, like a football team b down after the kickoff. Opposite them: Herbie sits, nervo the witness table. From the counsel table, Goodwin gives a reassuring look.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: For the record, will you state your name?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Herbert M. Stempel.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Will you give your address?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: 105-15 66th Road, Forest Hills 75, New York.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Were you one of the contestants in the program referred to as

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I was, yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: At what time?

dialogues.speaker: . HERBIE
dialogues.text: I participated from October 17, 1956, to December 5, 1956. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: And during that time were you ever furnished with the answers in advance?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE -
dialogues.text: Generally, I would receive the questions and answers on Tuesday, typed up.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: And the show aired when?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Wednesday. We‘d have a sort of rehearsal on Wednesday afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: A rehearsal?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: There was a great deal of . histrionics involved, for the show to proceed the way Mr. Enright planned it.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Stempel, what do you mean by *rehearsal’?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Well, for example, he told me how to breathe heavily into the microphone, and sigh, such as this. (Herbie sighs) He taught me how to stutter and say, in a plaintive voice, ‘I will take nine, nine points’.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: So it was all choreographed.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: How to bite my lip. How to mop my brow--he told me specifically not to smear my brow, but rather to pat for optimum effect. of course I'm shvitzing the whole time because they turned off the air conditioning.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, with your permission, we might at this point view a portion of ‘21’ taken from the program of the night of December 5.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Whenever you're ready. Goodwin signals a TECHNICIAN. A projector ROLLS....

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: the Stempel/Van Doren contest...And it's as Herbie descri to the letter...He sighs. He says plaintively, ‘Nine, nin points’. The gallery starts to TITTER...

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE WITNESS TABLE
dialogues.text: Herbie, warming to the gallery, provides commentary.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: There. There’s the lip biting.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, we see. LAUGHTER from the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Finally I was told to open my eyes and with a dazzling smile give the answer and explode when Jack Barry said, ‘That is right’.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Herbie opens his eyes. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: His paper was the Emporia Gazette.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: That is right! Herbie explodes.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON- -HERBIE
dialogues.text: thoroughly pleased, as the gallery laughs out loud... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know where he got it all--some article on mass psychology he read in Esquire.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Barry and the cameras turn to Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Here. Watch Van Doren. He's even better at it than I am.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Stempel, are you suggesting that Charles Van Doren also received the answers?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Of course he got the answers! (off kinescope) Look at him. You see? With the brow. Patting--not smearing.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Stempel, do you have any direct knowledge that Charles Van Doren received the answers? Goodwin tries to signal Herbie. But Herbie’s intent on th kinescope...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: What? No, I mean--look at him! It's the same thing!

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Did you rehearse together?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Well, it wouldn’t make much sense for me to take a dive and not fix Van Doren.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Stempel, have you ever received any psychiatric treatment of any kind? REPORTER #1 runs in. Leans close to REPORTER #2. They bot out. Herbie, distracted, turns back to Congressman #4.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five sessions a week--that’s pretty extensive, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I believe we can all use a little help at various times in our lives,

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Is it possible that any of your testimony is motivated by animosity toward Mr. Enright? REPORTER #3 runs in. Whispers to REPORTER #4. Who leans o explains to REPORTER #5.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: (whisper) Van Doren made a statement, They all RUN from the chamber. Herbie notices them as the Congressmen bear down...

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Stempel?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I don't feel that he lived up to his agreements. [ think he Promised certain things just to shut me up--

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: So you resent the hell out of him. Are those your feelings?

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: I’m here to tell the truth. Those are my feelings. What’s your feeling? A BUZZ builds in the hall. More reporters jump up, run ou Staffers whisper in the ears of Congressmen...

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Charles van Doren is a professor at Columbia University. Master’s degree in astrophysics. Ph.p. in literature. Hails from one of the most prominent intellectual families in the country. Isn‘t it just possible that you got the answers and he didn’t? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Q£ course it’s possible--as a matter of classical logic-- A mad RUSH for the doors now...The Chairman gavels...Herb distracted, presses on...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: --I was simply drawing your attention to an inferential proof rather than-- REPORTER #6 signals to a colleague, cries out.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Van Doren’s made a statement! CHAOS as the chamber empties. Herbie leans into the micro Taps it LOUDLY.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Excuse mel I’m making a statement!

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Adjourned till one o'clock. The Chairman gavels. Herbie stands as the room empties...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: This is a statement. What I’m saying is a statement. I’m telling the trutht

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LATER. CHAIRMAN’S OFFICE. The Chairman, enraged, a TELEGRAM in hand, circles Goodwi

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Who the hell is Charles van Doren? What is he, somebody on television?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You don’t know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: All I know is in the last hour I've received over 200 telegrams from Fayetteville asking me why I’m persecuting poor Charles van Doren and why won’t I let him defend himself. Why isn’t he on the schedule of witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: GOCDWIN
dialogues.text: Well, sir, if I could refer you to the Barenblatt and Sweezey cases--

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: I wa: = his ass in that hearing room tomorrow. Understood?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Will you tell me what he said?

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘Mr. Van Doren has made himself available to members of the committee staff. He has advised them that at no time was he supplied any questions or answers with respect to his appearances on ‘21’, He was never assisted in any form and he has no knowledge of any assistance having been given to any other contestant. Signed, Charles van Doren.‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie at the front door. Moves to knock. Stops. Moves a Stops. Turns. Returns. Moves to knock. Can't do it. Heads the steps, up the gravel driveway. The door opens behind him.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie sits by the fire. The Professor pours them beth a Scotch, joins his son.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: So what’s the news, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, uh, there’s--it seems there’s this Congressional committee that‘s--they’re investigating the quiz shows.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I read about that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I thought you might've. Anyway, they--well, it seems they want to call me. To testify.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Oh, I've testified before. For the National Endowment. It’s nothing. CHARLI. I think this is a little different.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: You'll run circles around them. It’s not exactly Jefferson and Lincoln down there, you know.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m just not sure, you know, what to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Just tell them the truth--you’1ll do fine. The real issue, Charlie, is the way this is distracting you from your teaching--this and that program in the morning, although you insist it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dad- -

dialogues.speaker: . THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: You‘re a good teacher. I’m not just saying it because you’re my son. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dad--I can’t tell them the truth.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Why not? From what I understand, all it was was this bunch of frauds showing off an erudition they didn’t really have--basically pretending to be Charles Van Doren. All you have to do is--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You see, the problem, Dad, is it seems I was one of those frauds. The Professor stares at Charlie. Unbelieving...

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: They gave you the answers? Charlie gets up, agitated. Starts to pace...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Not at first. At first they just asked me questions they already knew I knew the answers to. Well, we ran through those in five weeks. I still didn't want them to actually give me the answers. So I had them give me the questions. And I’d go look up the answers. Well, I didn’t have the time, and finally, it just seemed silly. So-- ‘ THE PROFESSOR They gave you the answers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What was I going to do at that point? Disillusion the whole goddam country?

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: They gave you $129,000 to answer questions they knew you knew. Now that’s inflation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) You’re not being very helpful. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: {angry back) I’m sorry. I’m an old man. It's just all very hard for me to comprehend.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s television, Dad. It’s just... television.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: For what? What was it? Was it the money?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, it was--I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: It was a goddam quiz show, Charlie. —

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘An ill-favoured thing, sir--’

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: This is no time te Play games.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (savagely) ine ‘, It was mine.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (cight back) The two turn away from each other. Embarrassed by the exp of feeling. Hurt by the truth.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. I'm just sorry you’ll be dragged into all this.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I’1l come with you down to Washington.

dialogues.speaker: , CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You really don‘t--

dialogues.speaker: THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: T won't hear a word about it. (with sympathy) My God, son--what are you going to tell that committee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As VIPs are ushered in, Herbie strains to see through the doorway. A Capitol Hill COP blacks him.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: You gotta let me in. Let me int! It’s my hearing! cop If you don’t have a ticket you don’t go in.

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: What about a subpoena? Just let me go inside and I'll have my close friend the Chairman write me a subpoena. The Cop backs Herbie off with his NIGHTSTICK...

dialogues.speaker: HERBIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay! Enough! (mutters) Asshole. He wanders off down the hall. Turns a corner and SEES something...Hides behind the corner. Looks again. HERBIE’S POV Charlie, sitting in a shaft of sunlight, alone on the sta

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SAME TIME. CHAIRMAN’S OFFICE. Goodwin sits behind closed doors, alone with a WITNESS.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: -+-The Chairman's instructions are to get you up there as promptly as possible and for the questions to take no longer than 15 minutes. He wants you to receive all questions in advance and for me to thank you for the courtesy of attending this hearing. Goodwin hands over the questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Kintner takes the pages, looks them over.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: You knew all along, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: Young man, I am the President of the National Broadcasting Company. Our number one show, a show worth literally millions of dollars, that beat ‘I Love Lucy’ in the tatings...The idea that I wouldn’t know every detail of that show's operation--frankly, it’s insulting. (ironic) I never, never imagined they'd tamper with the honesty of that program.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: And they’1l let you off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: {off papers) This doesn’t seem like a grueling line of inquiry, does it? You're the only one I’m worried about. And you don‘t have anything.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: I have Dan Enright.

dialogues.speaker: . KINTNER
dialogues.text: Dan Enright wants a future in television. The public has a short memory. But corporations never forget. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: He’s not that stupid. He knows he’s through.

dialogues.speaker: . KINTNER
dialogues.text: It might take five years, ten years. But he’ll be back. NBC goes on. Geritol goes on. (beat) Makes you wonder what you’ve accomplished, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry--I’m just starting.

dialogues.speaker: KINTNER
dialogues.text: Even the quiz shows‘1ll be back. They don’t have to be fixed--you could accomplish the same thing just making the questions easier. That's what Dan never understood. Herb Stempel, Van Doren--Dan went nuts trying to find people like that. But our audience wasn’t tuning in to watch some display of intellectual ability. They just wanted to watch the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin hurries in behind the Congressmen. Leans over to Chairman, whispers. The Chairman excuses a WITNESS.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: The witness is excused. The committee calls Charles Van Doren. PANDEMONIUM! PHOTOGRAPHERS press in...FLASH! FLASH! FLASH Charlie enters, The Professor by his side. In the hubbub, sneaks in, squeezes into the back of the room... The Professor takes a seat in the gallery. Charlie sits a witness table. The room quiets.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Will you state your name?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Charles Van Doren. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: / CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Will you give your address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 Washington Square, New York City.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Do you solemnly swear the testimony you give to this committee to be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I do.
as sits at the counsel table. Glances over toward the sid aisle...DOUBLETAKES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Herbie CRAWLS on his hands and knees up the aisle, get a better view...

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: I am advised that you have a statement which you would prefer to read at the outset?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. May I ask first, sir, if I may have a glass of water. I’m sorry to bother you. trying to A PAGE brings Charlie a glass of water. With glee, Herbie watches his nemesis squirm...

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: You may proceed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I would give almost anything I have to reverse the course of my life in the last year. The past doesn't change for anyone. But at least I can learn from the past. I’ve learned a lot about life. (more) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE (Cont'd) I’ve learned a lot about myself, and about the responsibilities any man has to his fellow men. I've learned a lot about good and evil--they’re not always what they appear to be. I was involved, deeply involved, ina deception. I have deceived my friends, and I had millions of them. Ina sense, I was like a child who refuses to admit a fact in the hope that it will go away. Of course, it did not go away. There was one way out, and that was simply to tell the truth. 1 finally realized what I should have known before, that the truth is always the best way, indeed it is the only way, to promote and protect faith, the only thing with which a man can live. That is why IT am here today. A long SILENCE...Goodwin sits and watches, stunned...Herb his moment of VINDICATION. And then...

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Van Doren, I want to compliment you for that statement.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Van Doren, I would like to join with the chairman in commending you for the soul-searching fortitude that is displayed in your statement.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Van Doren, I just want to add my kudos. I have listened to many witnesses in both civil and criminal matters, and yours is the most soul-searching confession I think I have heard in a long time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, sir. And then CONGRESSMAN #4, a curmudgeonly public servant, b in.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Van Doren, I’m also from New York. Another part of New York. I am happy that you made the statement, but I cannot agree with most of my colleagues.
